messageBody:
I also found the FAQ confusing on this point. I'm sure it's my ignorance of
Java that causes me not to follow your helpful reply. Here's a class (and a
few questions below):

public class AllTests extends TestCase
{
public AllTests(String name) { super(name); }

public static Test suite()
{
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
suite.add(MyTest.suite());
suite.add(MyOtherTest.suite());
TestSetup wrapper= new TestSetup(suite)
{
public void setUp()
{
oneTimeSetUp();
}
public void tearDown()
{
oneTimeTearDown();
}
};
return wrapper;
}

public void oneTimeSetup()
{
}

public void oneTimeTearDown()
{
}

}

(1) Is there a better way?
(2) Will the variables defined in oneTimeSetup be in scope inside MyTest?
(3) How can I reuse the fixture defined in this class for another set of
tests?
(4) Will the fixtures defined the suite's TestCase's still be created?

>
> When using the TestSetup decorator, Implementing oneTimeSetUp() is not
> absolutely essential, but why would you want to use the test decorator
> unless oneTimeSetUp was your aim?
>
> The main point of the TestSetup decorator is to provide the ability to
> perform one-time setup and teardown, i.e. oneTimeSetUp() is
> run once before
> all of your tests (not each, but all), and oneTimeTearDown()
> is run once
> after all of your tests complete. If you don't need this
> functionality,
> then you don't need the TestSetup decorator. You may remove
> the following
> code from your suite() method:
> TestSetup wrapper = new TestSetup(suite) {
> public void setUp () {
> oneTimeSetUp();
> }
> and have it return suite instead of the TestSetup that it
> currently returns.
>
> Cheers,
>
> _chas_
